metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Django if Tag
If Statement
An if statement evaluates a variable and executes a block of code if the value is true.
content.html: An if statement evaluates a variable and executes a block of code if the value is true.

content.code:
{%

if

greeting

==

1

%}


<
h1
>
Hello
</
h1
>


{%

endif

%}
content.code_html:
{% if greeting == 1 %}
  <h1>Hello</h1>
{% endif %}

content.text: Elif
The elif keyword says "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".
content.html: The elif keyword says "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".

content.code:

if

greeting

==

1

%}


<
h1
>

h1
>


{%

elif

greeting

==

2

%}


<
h1
>
Welcome
</
h1
>


{%

endif

%}
content.code_html:
{% if greeting == 1 %}
  <h1>Hello</h1>
{% elif greeting == 2 %}
  <h1>Welcome</h1>
{% endif %}

content.text: Else
The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.
content.html: The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.

{% else %}

{% endif %}

content.text: Operators

The above examples uses the == operator, which is used to check if a variable is equal to a value, but there are many other operators you can use, or you can even drop the operator if you just want to check if a variable is not empty:

content.text: Parentheses are not allowed in if statements in Django, so when you combine and and or operators, it is important to know that parentheses are added for and but not for or .
content.html: Parentheses are not allowed in if statements in Django, so when you combine and and or operators, it is important to know that parentheses are added for and but not for or.

content.text: is
Check if two objects are the same.
content.html: Check if two objects are the same.

content.text: This operator is different from the == operator, because the == operator checks the values of two objects, but the is operator checks the identity of two objects.
content.html: This operator is different from the == operator, because the == operator checks the values of two objects, but the is operator checks the identity of two objects.

content.text: In the view we have two objects, x and y , with the same values:
content.html: In the view we have two objects, x and y, with the same values:

content.code:

django
.
http
import
HttpResponse

from
django
.
template
import
loader

def
testing
(
request
)
:

template
=
loader
.
get_template
(
'template.html'
)

context
=

{


'x'
:

[
'Apple'
,

'Banana'
,

'Cherry'
]
,


'y'
:

[
'Apple'
,

'Banana'
,

'Cherry'
]
,


}


return

HttpResponse
(
template
.
render
(
context
,
request
)
)
content.code_html:
from django.http import HttpResponse
from django.template import loader

def testing(request):
  template = loader.get_template('template.html')
  context = {
    'x': ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry'], 
    'y': ['Apple', 'Banana', 'Cherry'], 
  }
  return HttpResponse(template.render(context, request))

content.text: The two objects have the same value, but is it the same object?
content.html: The two objects have the same value, but is it the same object?

{%

content.code_html:
{% if x is y %}
  <h1>YES</h1>
{% else %}
  <h1>NO</h1>
{% endif %}

content.text: How can two objects be the same? Well, if you have two objects that points to the same object, then the is operator evaluates to true:
content.html: How can two objects be the same? Well, if you have two objects that points to the same object, then the is operator evaluates to true:

content.text: We will demonstrate this by using the {% with %} tag, which allows us to create variables in the template:
content.html: We will demonstrate this by using the {% with %} tag, which allows us to create variables in the template:

content.code_html:
{% with var1=x var2=x %}
  {% if var1 is var2 %}
    <h1>YES</h1>
  {% else %}
    <h1>NO</h1>
  {% endif %}
{% endwith %}
